Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Antimicrobial Sutures in Hand Trauma Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This multicentre feasibility randomised controlled trial was conducted at three NHS hospitals in the UK.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with hand or wrist injuries requiring surgery.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received antimicrobial sutures, while the control group received standard sutures.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a definitive trial comparing antimicrobial sutures to standard sutures in reducing SSI.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was feasibility, measured by recruitment, compliance, and retention over 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was 1:1, stratified by age and injury type, using a secure online service.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From March to November 2022, 116 participants were randomised (60 intervention, 56 control).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Retention was 57.5% at 30 days, 52% at 90 days, and 45.1% at 6 months.

Result_Outcome.evidence: SSI incidence was over 20% in both groups.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to treatment allocation were reported.

Funding.evidence: The study was supported by the UK Trauma Patient and Public Involvement Group.
